trial_identification.studytitle: Artesunate-pyronaridine and artemisinin-naphthoquine combination therapies for Papua New Guinean children with uncomplicated malaria infections
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Efficacy of artesunate-pyronaridine and artemisinin-naphthoquine combination therapies compared with standard artemether-lumefantrine in children from Papua New Guinea with uncomplicated malaria who are monitored for recurrent malaria over 42 days post-treatment

interventions.interventions: Artesunate-pyronaridine (Pyramax) as artesunate 3 mg/kg and pyronaridine base 10 mg/kg once-daily for three days or artemisinin-naphthoquine (Arco) as artemisinin 20 mg/kg and naphthoquine phosphate 8 mg/kg once-daily for three days. Both drug regimens will be given orally with water. Doses will be calculated from body weight to the nearest whole sachet of granules (Pyramax) or tablets (Arco).
interventions.comparator: Artemether-lumefantrine (Novartis Pharma, Basel, Switzerland) as artemether 1.7 mg/kg and lumefantrine 10 mg/kg twice-daily for three days given orally with milk. Doses will be calculated from body weight to the nearest whole tablet.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Recrudescent Plasmodium falciparum after correction for re-infections using PCR genotyping of polymorphic parasite loci in children with falciparum malaria
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 42 days after initiation of treatment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Appearance of any Plasmodium vivax parasitaemia on blood smear after treatment for vivax malaria.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 42 days after initiation of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Reappearance of PCR-uncorrected P. falciparum parasitemia on blood smear after treatment of falciparum malaria
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 42 days after initiation of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appearance of any P. vivax parasitemia on blood smear after treatment of falciparum malaria
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 42 days after initiation of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appearance of P. falciparum gametocytes on blood smear after treatment of falciparum malaria
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 42 days after initiation of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appearance of P. vivax gametocytes on blood smear within 42 daysa fter treatment of vivax malaria
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 42 days after initiation of treatment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Children with an axillary temperature >37.5 degrees Centigrade or fever during the previous 24 hours with either P. falciparum (>1000 asexual parasites per microlitre whole blood) or P. vivax (>250 per microlitre) on blood smear microscopy
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Features of severity, treatment with a study drug or other antimalarial in the previous 28 days, clinical or laboratory evidence of another infection or co-morbidity including malnutrition

trial_design.concealment: Eligible children will be enrolled at participating field sites after parental informed consent has been obtained. The study is open label but randomisation will be by computer generated code contained in a sealed envelope to be opened at the time of recruitment.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomization table created by a computer software (i.e., computerised sequence generation)

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: School of Medicine and Pharmacology, Fremantle Hospital, PO Box 480, Fremantle, Western Australia 6959

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Papua New Guinea Insitute of Medical Research
secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: P O Box 60, Goroka, Eastern Highlands Province 411

ethicsAndSummary.summary: We recently found that the WHO-recommended combination antimalarial therapy artemether-lumefantrine and the candidate regimen dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine were not fully effective for both falciparum and vivax malaria in young Papua New Guinean children, a group at high risk of complications and death. We plan to study two new combinations (artesunate-pyronaridine and artemisinin-naphthoquine) in the hope that at least one will prove superior and be used in treatment programs in PNG and similar countries.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Government of PNG, Department of Health, PO Box 807, Waigani NCD 131
